markdownRemark.html:
Score: 87.5

hollywoodreporter.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of a weekly magazine covering the film and entertainment industries in Hollywood.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Eldridge Industries, a private equity firm, owns and operates The Hollywood Reporter and its website, both known as THR.  

Content

THR publishes news related to the film and TV industries, including reviews, interviews with actors, and box office updates. The site also covers political and technology news, culture, and style. THR reports through text and video, including segments such as “Where Hollywood Eats” and “In Studio with The Hollywood Reporter,” which provide exclusive interviews with actors in popular TV series and movies. Videos link to advertisements that take viewers away from the website.

Credibility

THR has a reporting and editorial staff that writes stories for the magazine and website. Headlines are straightforward, and accurately reflect the content of stories. In “Movies,” opinion and reviews are mixed with news, and the distinction is not always clear. For example, a story that appeared in 2018, “Toxic Fandom Is Killing ‘Star Wars,’” was an editorial that readers could have mistaken for news because it was not labeled as opinion.

The Hollywood Reporter does not state its corrections policy, but NewsGuard found examples of recently corrected stories. Corrections are noted at the bottom of stories.

Transparency

Original stories on THR.com list authors’ names, and provide their contact information. The About Us page lists a staff directory, but without individual contact information. Readers can call the newsdesk or send inquiries to a general email address. “From the Web” stories are not clearly labeled as advertisements and often link to stories about movies, celebrities, and entertainment. Readers could easily mistake sponsored links for other THR content.

The site did not reply to NewsGuard email and voicemail seeking comment on its advertising policies and on the lack of information about its content creators.

History

The magazine was one of the first daily movie-industry newspapers in Hollywood when it was founded in 1930 by William Wilkerson. THR was transformed from a five-times-a-week publication into a glossy weekly magazine in 2010 to remain competitive in the market for entertainment news, which had grown to include numerous blogs and websites. The website domain was registered in 1995.

Correction: An earlier version of this Nutrition Label said incorrectly that the site did not publish corrections. The label and criteria have been updated.

Written by:
Evan Haddad

Edited by:
Joyce Purnick Eric Effron
